data.title: Build rpm package on Fedora 21
data.body:
The rpm CI builds were failing after a recent upgrade to a new Fedora 20 container.

Fedora 21 came out last December so lets starts building on that.

data.title: Rename / Disable "Reopen Last Item"
data.body:
Suggestions:
1. Disable "Reopen Last Item" until a document has been closed.
2. Rename "Reopen Last Item" to "Reopen Closed Document"

Justification:
In the absence of a "Open Recent...", the wording of the "Reopen Last Item" menu option is confusing. Nearly every time I use Atom as a new user, I launch Atom and go to File > Reopen Last Item. It doesn't do anything. See #5718.

As I understand it, it seems to actually be more similar to a browser's "Reopen Closed Tab", no? Chrome has "Reopen Closed Tab". Until this is made moot by #4241, we should rename that menu item to "Reopen Closed Document" or something to that effect.

Part of the confusion is that "Reopen Last Item" has the same placement as the standard "Open Recent..." menu option, but they don't operate the same way. We should disable it until Atom is in a state where the menu item actually does anything.

data.title: Editor does not autoscroll to undo location
data.body:
- Open `package.json` from atom/atom in Atom
- Type an `a` on the first line
- Scroll to the botom
- Undo

Editor is still scrolled to the bottom instead of to the top where the edit was just undone.

data.title: Update copyright
data.body: Wooo 2015 :beers:

data.title: Delete Line deletes more than one line if the line has multiple selections
Pane focus (left, right) doesn't work
data.body:
Hi, I hope I'm not mistaken by posting here and the panes are part of Atom's core. I'm using these keybindings to move between different panes.

``` cson
'body':
  'ctrl-alt-left': 'window:focus-pane-on-left' # works
  'ctrl-alt-right': 'window:focus-pane-on-right' # works
  'ctrl-alt-up': 'window:focus-pane-on-above' # doesn't work
  'ctrl-alt-down': 'window:focus-pane-on-below' # doesn't work
```

The problem is, the last two don't work. The first two do. All of them map to the correct commands in Atom (the key binding resolver shows the correct mapping for all of them in green). 

There are no logs in the dev-tools console nor the OSX Console.app. The problem as well occurs in safe mode. Thanks for your help.

I'm using OSX version: 10.10.2 (14C109) and Atom version: 0.188.0.

data.title: Dumped core
data.body:
Hello github,

After reading couple reviews in internet regarding your text editor decided to give it a shot.

Your text editor is outstanding, but what worries me is that it is trying to connect to some ip and my firewall is set to deny unauthorized (in/out) connections. 

I've used the latest build on archlinux.

Shortly after it is started the whole editor just disappears, and **dmesg** , **journalctl --catalog --lines --priority=0..3** , **coredumpctl info** reveal additional information. **gdb** helps even further with:

```
coredumpctl gdb 1894
           PID: 1894 (atom)
           UID: 1000 (frost)
           GID: 100 (users)
        Signal: 11 (SEGV)
     Timestamp: Thu 2015-03-26 01:41:29 EET (26min ago)
  Command Line: /usr/share/atom/atom --type=gpu-process --channel=1869.0.606562709 --no-sandbox --supports-dual-gpus=false --gpu-driver-bug-workarounds=1,24,36,39 --disable-accelerated-video-decode --gpu-vendor-id=0x1002 --gpu-device-id=0x9616 --gpu-driver-vendor --gpu-driver-versio
    Executable: /usr/share/atom/atom
 Control Group: /user.slice/user-1000.slice/session-c1.scope
          Unit: session-c1.scope
         Slice: user-1000.slice
       Session: c1
     Owner UID: 1000 (frost)
       Boot ID: 938648a15754441ab3f28968d36a1772
    Machine ID: 1a9fbe7f4dd94e12b4f7add871bf1f29
      Hostname: localhost
      Coredump: /var/lib/systemd/coredump/core.atom.1000.938648a15754441ab3f28968d36a1772.1894.1427326889000000.lz4
       Message: Process 1894 (atom) of user 1000 dumped core.

/usr/share/atom/atom: No such file or directory.
[New LWP 1894]
[New LWP 1898]
Core was generated by `/usr/share/atom/atom --type=gpu-process --channel=1869.0.606562709 --no-sandbox'.
Program terminated with signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
#0  0x00007fac53772e2c in ?? ()
```

I've taken a picture, but for some reason I'm not allowed to attach pictures, so here it is as external link - https://i.imgur.com/KSTbOgT.png

edit: If you want me to attach the compressed coredump archives just let me know.

Cheers

data.title: Periodically have to reset Exclude VCS Ignored Paths
data.body: Pretty regularly, when I create a file in a project, ctrl-p won't reveal the new file in results unless I drill into Preferences, check, and then uncheck, Exclude VCS Ignored Paths. After that, the new file shows up as expected.

data.title: 1.0 API preview mode
data.body:
This pull request adds a new command line flag (`-1` or `--one`) that will launch Atom with no core deprecated APIs so you can test out the 1.0 API experience where APIs will be missing instead of present but logging deprecations.

So things like `atom.workspaceView` will be unavailable and so you can use this flag to test out that your packages will work correctly when 1.0 comes out.

The basic flow here is to check `Grim.includeDeprecatedAPIs` in places and to co-locate all the prototype methods at the bottom of the file so they can all be deleted easily once 1.0 ships.
### Deprecations To Update
- [x] atom/atom
- [x] https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/pull/77
- [x] https://github.com/atom/event-kit/pull/5
- [x] https://github.com/atom/first-mate/pull/41
- [x] markdown-preview
- [x] https://github.com/atom/node-pathwatcher/pull/68
- [x] https://github.com/atom/scoped-property-store/pull/13
- [x] https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/55
- [x] wrap-guide

Refs #5164

data.title: Add support for jasmine 2.0
data.body:
#### Motivation

Currently, any npm modules we work on (e.g. `text-document`) need to use jasmine 1.3 so we can run specs in Atom, which is really useful for debugging. Without Atom's monkey-patched `waitsFor`, Jasmine 1.3 is basically unusable for testing async code (it only supports polling, no callbacks). Rather than have `text-document` and other libraries vendor atom/atom's customized version of jasmine 1.3, we should just use jasmine 2.
#### Changes

This allows packages and npm-modules to opt-in to using Jasmine-2.0 for the `application:run-package-specs` command in Atom. Packages opt in by adding `atom-jasmine: "^2.0.0"` to the `engines` object in their `package.json`.

Currently, when using Jasmine 2, `spec-helper` is not loaded. I think it would be nice to eventually stop using the miscellaneous global functions defined in that file. Some of them (e.g. the non-standard `jasmine.advanceClock`) duplicate functionality that is built into jasmine.

I am thinking that some community members might be interested in upgrading individual package's test suites to use Jasmine-2.0. We could make `good-first` issues for doing that in various packages.
- [x] Make the `AtomReporter` support the jasmine 2 reporter API
- [x] Make sure `fit`, `fdescribe` et al work w/ jasmine 2
- [x] Make sure `apm test` works w/ jasmine 2
#### Questions
- [ ] This PR also removes the `application:run-all-specs` command. It doesn't seem like that command is used anymore, and it would have been difficult to preserve it while adding support for Jasmine-2.0 in the 
  AtomReporter. Also, it would be very difficult to support that command's functionality if individual packages started to migrate to Jasmine-2.0.
- [ ] Is the `engines.atom-jasmine` the right way to do this?

/cc @atom/core @atom/non-github-maintainers I'm not sure if it's overly aggressive to get rid of `run-all-specs` command. What do you think?

Refs #5393.

data.title: Enable deprecations in all windows
data.body:
Previously deprecations were only shown in dev and test windows.

Removing this check enables it for all windows.

data.title: Add Root Folder from command line
data.body:
The tree-view command "Add Root Folder" is very useful. Frequently I want to open multiple projects in one editor window, with each project as a root folder. This enables things like tree-view's "Hide VCS Ignored Files" to actually work. Other packages also require the root of a repository to be a root folder in tree-view, such as git-blame, for example. Currently, opening a directory from the command line results in opening a new Atom editor window.

``` shell
atom /foo/bar # creates new window with /foo/bar the single root folder in tree-view
atom /foo/baz # creates another window
```

I have a feeling issue atom/tree-view#393 would block implementing a feature like this, but it would be very nice to support something like the following.

``` shell
atom /foo/bar # creates new window with /foo/bar the single root folder in tree-view
atom -a /foo/baz # adds /foo/baz as a root folder to an existing window (most recently used?)
```

data.title: Clicking on package names in the Settings > Install UI often doesn't do anything
data.body: Especially when the package has not been installed

data.title: Default Settings tab to Install section
data.body: Most of the time when I visit Settings, I intend to install something. If other users feel this way, could we have the Settings tab to open the _Install_ section by default, for speed?

data.title: Allow Command+W to close windows, not just tabs
data.body: On Mac OS X, many applications allow users to close tabs and windows with the same hotkey, `Command + w`. Could Atom respect this convention as well?

data.title: Wrong keyboard layout for keybindings
data.body:
Keybindings use a different keyboard-layout than the editor.
I have a swiss-german layout which works perfectly inside the editor.
In the keybinding resolver however, I see, that for example instead of a "?" it recognises a "{".
That makes it impossible to use certain keybindings and also hard to configure them.
## Repro Steps
1. Start the keybinding resolver and then type a "?" on a swiss-german keyboard. You will see that it wrote a "?" in the editor, but a "{" was recognised by the keybinding resolver.

**Expected:** Use the right keyboard layout also for keybindings
**Actual:** It uses a different keyboard-layout for the keybindings than in the editor.
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.187.0
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.21.3
- **OS:**         linux 3.17.6-1-ARCH
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.142.0
  - npm  2.5.1
  - node 0.10.35
  - python 2.7.9
  - git 2.2.2

---

<small>This report was created in and posted from the Atom editor using the package `bug-report` v0.6.3.</small>

data.title: Atom should save new files where the last opened/saved file was
data.body:
When you create a new buffer and hit save, Atom will present me with a save dialog and the default selected folder is the project root. That's almost never the place I want to put a file.

Sublime Text was a lot smarter with this -- although I do not remember the exact heuristics. For example, it would propose saving the file in the same location where the file you last had opened was. This worked really well for me: Usually I create a new file by splitting an existing file, creating a test for a module (and those two are in directly adjacent directories) or similar.

Even if I want to save to the root directory, which is the current behavior, navigating upwards in the file save dialog is really simple.

PS: I am using Atom 0.187.0

data.title: fix typo
data.body:
`apm test` -> `npm test`

no contribution too small?

data.title: Added delete-to-next/previous-word-boundary
data.body:
This is better behavior for alt-del/backspace operations, is less "greedy" and doesn't eat up excess characters.
Also set default key mappings to these, feel free to trash my changes to keymaps/darwin.cson. Though I do feel this should be default behavior, personally.
